    30|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# dataclass decorator takes.  For all of these tables, when I talk
    31|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# about init=, repr=, eq=, order=, unsafe_hash=, or frozen=, I'm
    32|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# referring to the arguments to the @dataclass decorator.  When
    33|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# checking if a dunder method already exists, I mean check for an
    34|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# entry in the class's __dict__.  I never check to see if an attribute
    35|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# is defined in a base class.
    36|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
    37|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# Key:
    38|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=========+=========================================+
    39|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# + Value   | Meaning                                 |
    40|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=========+=========================================+
    41|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | <blank> | No action: no method is added.          |
    42|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +---------+-----------------------------------------+
    43|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | add     | Generated method is added.              |
    44|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +---------+-----------------------------------------+
    45|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | raise   | TypeError is raised.                    |
    46|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +---------+-----------------------------------------+
    47|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | None    | Attribute is set to None.               |
    48|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=========+=========================================+
    49|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
    50|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __init__
    51|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#
    52|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#   +--- init= parameter
    53|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#   |
    54|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#   v     |       |       |
    55|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#         |  no   |  yes  |  <--- class has __init__ in __dict__?
    56|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
    57|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False |       |       |
    58|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+
    59|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | add   |       |  <- the default
    60|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
    61|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
    62|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __repr__
    63|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#
    64|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    +--- repr= parameter
    65|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    |
    66|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    v    |       |       |
    67|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#         |  no   |  yes  |  <--- class has __repr__ in __dict__?
    68|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
    69|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False |       |       |
    70|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+
    71|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | add   |       |  <- the default
    72|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
    73|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
    74|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
    75|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __setattr__
    76|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __delattr__
    77|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#
    78|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    +--- frozen= parameter
    79|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    |
    80|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    v    |       |       |
    81|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#         |  no   |  yes  |  <--- class has __setattr__ or __delattr__ in __dict__?
    82|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
    83|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False |       |       |  <- the default
    84|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+
    85|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | add   | raise |
    86|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
    87|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# Raise because not adding these methods would break the "frozen-ness"
    88|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# of the class.
    89|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
    90|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __eq__
    91|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#
    92|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    +--- eq= parameter
    93|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    |
    94|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    v    |       |       |
    95|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#         |  no   |  yes  |  <--- class has __eq__ in __dict__?
    96|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
    97|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False |       |       |
    98|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+
    99|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | add   |       |  <- the default
   100|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
   101|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   102|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __lt__
   103|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __le__
   104|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __gt__
   105|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __ge__
   106|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#
   107|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    +--- order= parameter
   108|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    |
   109|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    v    |       |       |
   110|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#         |  no   |  yes  |  <--- class has any comparison method in __dict__?
   111|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
   112|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False |       |       |  <- the default
   113|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+
   114|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | add   | raise |
   115|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+
   116|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# Raise because to allow this case would interfere with using
   117|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# functools.total_ordering.
   118|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   119|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __hash__
   120|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   121|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    +------------------- unsafe_hash= parameter
   122|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    |       +----------- eq= parameter
   123|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    |       |       +--- frozen= parameter
   124|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    |       |       |
   125|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#    v       v       v    |        |        |
   126|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#                         |   no   |  yes   |  <--- class has explicitly defined __hash__
   127|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+========+========+
   128|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False | False | False |        |        | No __eq__, use the base class __hash__
   129|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
   130|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False | False | True  |        |        | No __eq__, use the base class __hash__
   131|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
   132|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False | True  | False | None   |        | <-- the default, not hashable
   133|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
   134|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | False | True  | True  | add    |        | Frozen, so hashable, allows override
   135|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
   136|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | False | False | add    | raise  | Has no __eq__, but hashable
   137|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
   138|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | False | True  | add    | raise  | Has no __eq__, but hashable
   139|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
   140|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | True  | False | add    | raise  | Not frozen, but hashable
   141|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
   142|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# | True  | True  | True  | add    | raise  | Frozen, so hashable
   143|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# +=======+=======+=======+========+========+
   144|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# For boxes that are blank, __hash__ is untouched and therefore
   145|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# inherited from the base class.  If the base is object, then
   146|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# id-based hashing is used.
   147|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|#
   148|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# Note that a class may already have __hash__=None if it specified an
   149|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# __eq__ method in the class body (not one that was created by
   150|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# @dataclass).

   322|        42|            0|            0|  0.00%|def field(*, default=MISSING, default_factory=MISSING, init=True, repr=True,
   323|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|          hash=None, compare=True, metadata=None):
   324|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Return an object to identify dataclass fields.
   325|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   326|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    default is the default value of the field.  default_factory is a
   327|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    0-argument function called to initialize a field's value.  If init
   328|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    is True, the field will be a parameter to the class's __init__()
   329|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    function.  If repr is True, the field will be included in the
   330|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    object's repr().  If hash is True, the field will be included in
   331|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    the object's hash().  If compare is True, the field will be used
   332|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    in comparison functions.  metadata, if specified, must be a
   333|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    mapping which is stored but not otherwise examined by dataclass.
   334|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   335|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    It is an error to specify both default and default_factory.
   336|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """

   345|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Return a string representing each field of obj_name as a tuple
   346|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # member.  So, if fields is ['x', 'y'] and obj_name is "self",
   347|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # return "(self.x,self.y)".
   348|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|

   404|        41|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _field_assign(frozen, name, value, self_name):
   405|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # If we're a frozen class, then assign to our fields in __init__
   406|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # via object.__setattr__.  Otherwise, just use a simple
   407|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # assignment.
   408|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #
   409|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # self_name is what "self" is called in this function: don't
   410|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # hard-code "self", since that might be a field name.
   411|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if frozen:
   412|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return f'BUILTINS.object.__setattr__({self_name},{name!r},{value})'
   413|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return f'{self_name}.{name}={value}'
   414|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   415|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   416|        41|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _field_init(f, frozen, globals, self_name):
   417|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Return the text of the line in the body of __init__ that will
   418|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # initialize this field.
   419|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   420|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    default_name = f'_dflt_{f.name}'
   421|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if f.default_factory is not MISSING:
   422|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if f.init:
   423|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # This field has a default factory.  If a parameter is
   424|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # given, use it.  If not, call the factory.
   425|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|            globals[default_name] = f.default_factory
   426|        69|            0|            0|  0.00%|            value = (f'{default_name}() '
   427|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|                     f'if {f.name} is _HAS_DEFAULT_FACTORY '
   428|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|                     f'else {f.name}')
   429|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        else:
   430|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # This is a field that's not in the __init__ params, but
   431|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # has a default factory function.  It needs to be
   432|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # initialized here by calling the factory function,
   433|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # because there's no other way to initialize it.
   434|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   435|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # For a field initialized with a default=defaultvalue, the
   436|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # class dict just has the default value
   437|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # (cls.fieldname=defaultvalue).  But that won't work for a
   438|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # default factory, the factory must be called in __init__
   439|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # and we must assign that to self.fieldname.  We can't
   440|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # fall back to the class dict's value, both because it's
   441|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # not set, and because it might be different per-class
   442|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # (which, after all, is why we have a factory function!).
   443|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   444|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            globals[default_name] = f.default_factory
   445|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            value = f'{default_name}()'
   446|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    else:
   447|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # No default factory.
   448|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if f.init:
   449|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|            if f.default is MISSING:
   450|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                # There's no default, just do an assignment.
   451|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                value = f.name
   452|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|            elif f.default is not MISSING:
   453|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|                globals[default_name] = f.default
   454|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|                value = f.name
   455|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        else:
   456|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # This field does not need initialization.  Signify that
   457|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # to the caller by returning None.
   458|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            return None
   459|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   460|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Only test this now, so that we can create variables for the
   461|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # default.  However, return None to signify that we're not going
   462|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # to actually do the assignment statement for InitVars.
   463|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if f._field_type is _FIELD_INITVAR:
   464|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return None
   465|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   466|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Now, actually generate the field assignment.
   467|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return _field_assign(frozen, f.name, value, self_name)
(call)|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|# C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.9_3.9.3312.0_x64__qbz5n2kfra8p0\lib\dataclasses.py:404 _field_assign
   468|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   469|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   470|        41|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _init_param(f):
   471|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Return the __init__ parameter string for this field.  For
   472|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # example, the equivalent of 'x:int=3' (except instead of 'int',
   473|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # reference a variable set to int, and instead of '3', reference a
   474|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # variable set to 3).
   475|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if f.default is MISSING and f.default_factory is MISSING:
   476|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # There's no default, and no default_factory, just output the
   477|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # variable name and type.
   478|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        default = ''
   479|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif f.default is not MISSING:
   480|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # There's a default, this will be the name that's used to look
   481|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # it up.
   482|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|        default = f'=_dflt_{f.name}'
   483|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif f.default_factory is not MISSING:
   484|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # There's a factory function.  Set a marker.
   485|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|        default = '=_HAS_DEFAULT_FACTORY'
   486|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return f'{f.name}:_type_{f.name}{default}'
   487|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   488|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   489|         6|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _init_fn(fields, frozen, has_post_init, self_name, globals):
   490|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # fields contains both real fields and InitVar pseudo-fields.
   491|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   492|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Make sure we don't have fields without defaults following fields
   493|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # with defaults.  This actually would be caught when exec-ing the
   494|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # function source code, but catching it here gives a better error
   495|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # message, and future-proofs us in case we build up the function
   496|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # using ast.
   497|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    seen_default = False
   498|        45|  0.000997305|  2.21623e-05|  0.00%|    for f in fields:
   499|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Only consider fields in the __init__ call.
   500|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if f.init:
   501|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|            if not (f.default is MISSING and f.default_factory is MISSING):

   597|        41|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _is_classvar(a_type, typing):
   598|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # This test uses a typing internal class, but it's the best way to
   599|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # test if this is a ClassVar.
   600|        80|  0.000997543|  1.24693e-05|  0.00%|    return (a_type is typing.ClassVar
   601|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|            or (type(a_type) is typing._GenericAlias
   602|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|                and a_type.__origin__ is typing.ClassVar))
   603|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   604|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   605|        41|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _is_initvar(a_type, dataclasses):
   606|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # The module we're checking against is the module we're
   607|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # currently in (dataclasses.py).
   608|        80|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return (a_type is dataclasses.InitVar
   609|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|            or type(a_type) is dataclasses.InitVar)
   610|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   611|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   612|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _is_type(annotation, cls, a_module, a_type, is_type_predicate):
   613|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Given a type annotation string, does it refer to a_type in
   614|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # a_module?  For example, when checking that annotation denotes a
   615|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # ClassVar, then a_module is typing, and a_type is
   616|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # typing.ClassVar.
   617|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   618|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # It's possible to look up a_module given a_type, but it involves
   619|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # looking in sys.modules (again!), and seems like a waste since
   620|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # the caller already knows a_module.
   621|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   622|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # - annotation is a string type annotation
   623|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # - cls is the class that this annotation was found in
   624|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # - a_module is the module we want to match
   625|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # - a_type is the type in that module we want to match
   626|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # - is_type_predicate is a function called with (obj, a_module)
   627|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #   that determines if obj is of the desired type.
   628|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   629|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Since this test does not do a local namespace lookup (and
   630|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # instead only a module (global) lookup), there are some things it
   631|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # gets wrong.
   632|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   633|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # With string annotations, cv0 will be detected as a ClassVar:
   634|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #   CV = ClassVar
   635|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #   @dataclass
   636|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #   class C0:
   637|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #     cv0: CV
   638|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   639|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # But in this example cv1 will not be detected as a ClassVar:
   640|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #   @dataclass
   641|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #   class C1:
   642|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #     CV = ClassVar
   643|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #     cv1: CV
   644|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   645|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # In C1, the code in this function (_is_type) will look up "CV" in
   646|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # the module and not find it, so it will not consider cv1 as a
   647|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # ClassVar.  This is a fairly obscure corner case, and the best
   648|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # way to fix it would be to eval() the string "CV" with the
   649|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # correct global and local namespaces.  However that would involve
   650|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # a eval() penalty for every single field of every dataclass
   651|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # that's defined.  It was judged not worth it.
   652|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   653|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    match = _MODULE_IDENTIFIER_RE.match(annotation)
   654|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if match:
   655|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        ns = None
   656|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        module_name = match.group(1)
   657|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if not module_name:
   658|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # No module name, assume the class's module did
   659|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # "from dataclasses import InitVar".
   660|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            ns = sys.modules.get(cls.__module__).__dict__
   661|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        else:
   662|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # Look up module_name in the class's module.
   663|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            module = sys.modules.get(cls.__module__)
   664|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            if module and module.__dict__.get(module_name) is a_module:
   665|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                ns = sys.modules.get(a_type.__module__).__dict__
   666|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if ns and is_type_predicate(ns.get(match.group(2)), a_module):
   667|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            return True
   668|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return False
   669|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   670|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   671|        41|  0.000997543|  2.43303e-05|  0.00%|def _get_field(cls, a_name, a_type):
   672|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Return a Field object for this field name and type.  ClassVars
   673|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # and InitVars are also returned, but marked as such (see
   674|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # f._field_type).
   675|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   676|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # If the default value isn't derived from Field, then it's only a
   677|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # normal default value.  Convert it to a Field().
   678|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    default = getattr(cls, a_name, MISSING)
   679|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if isinstance(default, Field):
   680|        23|            0|            0|  0.00%|        f = default
   681|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    else:
   682|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if isinstance(default, types.MemberDescriptorType):
   683|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # This is a field in __slots__, so it has no default value.
   684|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            default = MISSING
   685|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|        f = field(default=default)
(call)|        17|            0|            0|  0.00%|# C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.9_3.9.3312.0_x64__qbz5n2kfra8p0\lib\dataclasses.py:322 field
   686|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   687|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Only at this point do we know the name and the type.  Set them.
   688|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    f.name = a_name
   689|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    f.type = a_type
   690|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   691|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Assume it's a normal field until proven otherwise.  We're next
   692|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # going to decide if it's a ClassVar or InitVar, everything else
   693|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # is just a normal field.
   694|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    f._field_type = _FIELD
   695|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   696|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # In addition to checking for actual types here, also check for
   697|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # string annotations.  get_type_hints() won't always work for us
   698|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # (see https://github.com/python/typing/issues/508 for example),
   699|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # plus it's expensive and would require an eval for every string
   700|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # annotation.  So, make a best effort to see if this is a ClassVar
   701|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # or InitVar using regex's and checking that the thing referenced
   702|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # is actually of the correct type.
   703|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   704|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # For the complete discussion, see https://bugs.python.org/issue33453
   705|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   706|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # If typing has not been imported, then it's impossible for any
   707|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # annotation to be a ClassVar.  So, only look for ClassVar if
   708|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # typing has been imported by any module (not necessarily cls's
   709|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # module).
   710|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    typing = sys.modules.get('typing')
   711|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if typing:
   712|        80|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if (_is_classvar(a_type, typing)
(call)|        40|  0.000997543|  2.49386e-05|  0.00%|# C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.9_3.9.3312.0_x64__qbz5n2kfra8p0\lib\dataclasses.py:597 _is_classvar
   713|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|            or (isinstance(f.type, str)
   714|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                and _is_type(f.type, cls, typing, typing.ClassVar,
   715|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                             _is_classvar))):
   716|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            f._field_type = _FIELD_CLASSVAR
   717|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   718|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # If the type is InitVar, or if it's a matching string annotation,
   719|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # then it's an InitVar.
   720|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if f._field_type is _FIELD:
   721|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # The module we're checking against is the module we're
   722|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # currently in (dataclasses.py).
   723|        40|            0|            0|  0.00%|        dataclasses = sys.modules[__name__]
   724|        80|  0.000997305|  1.24663e-05|  0.00%|        if (_is_initvar(a_type, dataclasses)

   753|        16|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _set_new_attribute(cls, name, value):
   754|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Never overwrites an existing attribute.  Returns True if the

   760|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   761|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   762|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# Decide if/how we're going to create a hash function.  Key is
   763|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# (unsafe_hash, eq, frozen, does-hash-exist).  Value is the action to
   764|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# take.  The common case is to do nothing, so instead of providing a
   765|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|# function that is a no-op, use None to signify that.
   766|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|

   768|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return None
   769|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   770|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _hash_add(cls, fields, globals):
   771|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    flds = [f for f in fields if (f.compare if f.hash is None else f.hash)]
   772|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return _hash_fn(flds, globals)
   773|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|

   809|         6|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _process_class(cls, init, repr, eq, order, unsafe_hash, frozen):
   810|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Now that dicts retain insertion order, there's no reason to use
   811|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # an ordered dict.  I am leveraging that ordering here, because
   812|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # derived class fields overwrite base class fields, but the order
   813|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # is defined by the base class, which is found first.
   814|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    fields = {}
   815|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   816|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if cls.__module__ in sys.modules:
   817|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|        globals = sys.modules[cls.__module__].__dict__
   818|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    else:
   819|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Theoretically this can happen if someone writes
   820|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # a custom string to cls.__module__.  In which case
   821|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # such dataclass won't be fully introspectable
   822|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # (w.r.t. typing.get_type_hints) but will still function
   823|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # correctly.
   824|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        globals = {}
   825|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   826|        10|            0|            0|  0.00%|    setattr(cls, _PARAMS, _DataclassParams(init, repr, eq, order,
(call)|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|# C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.9_3.9.3312.0_x64__qbz5n2kfra8p0\lib\dataclasses.py:300 __init__
   827|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                           unsafe_hash, frozen))
   828|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   829|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Find our base classes in reverse MRO order, and exclude
   830|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # ourselves.  In reversed order so that more derived classes
   831|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # override earlier field definitions in base classes.  As long as
   832|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # we're iterating over them, see if any are frozen.
   833|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    any_frozen_base = False
   834|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    has_dataclass_bases = False
   835|        10|            0|            0|  0.00%|    for b in cls.__mro__[-1:0:-1]:
   836|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Only process classes that have been processed by our
   837|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # decorator.  That is, they have a _FIELDS attribute.
   838|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|        base_fields = getattr(b, _FIELDS, None)
   839|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if base_fields is not None:
   840|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            has_dataclass_bases = True
   841|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            for f in base_fields.values():
   842|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                fields[f.name] = f
   843|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            if getattr(b, _PARAMS).frozen:
   844|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                any_frozen_base = True
   845|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   846|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Annotations that are defined in this class (not in base
   847|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # classes).  If __annotations__ isn't present, then this class
   848|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # adds no new annotations.  We use this to compute fields that are
   849|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # added by this class.
   850|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    #
   851|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Fields are found from cls_annotations, which is guaranteed to be
   852|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # ordered.  Default values are from class attributes, if a field
   853|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # has a default.  If the default value is a Field(), then it
   854|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # contains additional info beyond (and possibly including) the
   855|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # actual default value.  Pseudo-fields ClassVars and InitVars are
   856|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # included, despite the fact that they're not real fields.  That's
   857|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # dealt with later.
   858|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    cls_annotations = cls.__dict__.get('__annotations__', {})
   859|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|

   947|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Create __eq__ method.  There's no need for a __ne__ method,
   948|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # since python will call __eq__ and negate it.
   949|        55|            0|            0|  0.00%|        flds = [f for f in field_list if f.compare]

   954|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                   self_tuple, other_tuple,
   955|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                   globals=globals))
   956|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|

   958|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Create and set the ordering methods.

   962|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        for name, op in [('__lt__', '<'),
   963|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                         ('__le__', '<='),

   966|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                         ]:

   971|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                f'in class {cls.__name__}. Consider using '
   972|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                'functools.total_ordering')
   973|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   974|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if frozen:
   975|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        for fn in _frozen_get_del_attr(cls, field_list, globals):
   976|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            if _set_new_attribute(cls, fn.__name__, fn):
   977|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                raise TypeError(f'Cannot overwrite attribute {fn.__name__} '
   978|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                f'in class {cls.__name__}')
   979|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   980|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Decide if/how we're going to create a hash function.
   981|        10|            0|            0|  0.00%|    hash_action = _hash_action[bool(unsafe_hash),
   982|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|                               bool(eq),
   983|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|                               bool(frozen),
   984|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|                               has_explicit_hash]
   985|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if hash_action:
   986|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # No need to call _set_new_attribute here, since by the time

   998|         7|            0|            0|  0.00%|def dataclass(cls=None, /, *, init=True, repr=True, eq=True, order=False,
   999|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|              unsafe_hash=False, frozen=False):
  1000|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Returns the same class as was passed in, with dunder methods
  1001|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    added based on the fields defined in the class.
  1002|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1003|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    Examines PEP 526 __annotations__ to determine fields.
  1004|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1005|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    If init is true, an __init__() method is added to the class. If
  1006|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    repr is true, a __repr__() method is added. If order is true, rich
  1007|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    comparison dunder methods are added. If unsafe_hash is true, a
  1008|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    __hash__() method function is added. If frozen is true, fields may
  1009|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    not be assigned to after instance creation.
  1010|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """
  1011|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1012|        10|            0|            0|  0.00%|    def wrap(cls):
  1013|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return _process_class(cls, init, repr, eq, order, unsafe_hash, frozen)
(call)|         5|    0.0314233|   0.00628467|  0.04%|# C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.9_3.9.3312.0_x64__qbz5n2kfra8p0\lib\dataclasses.py:809 _process_class
  1014|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1015|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # See if we're being called as @dataclass or @dataclass().
  1016|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if cls is None:
  1017|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # We're called with parens.
  1018|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return wrap
  1019|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1020|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # We're called as @dataclass without parens.
  1021|         5|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return wrap(cls)
(call)|         5|    0.0314233|   0.00628467|  0.04%|# C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.9_3.9.3312.0_x64__qbz5n2kfra8p0\lib\dataclasses.py:1012 wrap

  1024|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def fields(class_or_instance):
  1025|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Return a tuple describing the fields of this dataclass.
  1026|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1027|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    Accepts a dataclass or an instance of one. Tuple elements are of
  1028|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    type Field.
  1029|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """
  1030|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1031|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Might it be worth caching this, per class?
  1032|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    try:
  1033|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        fields = getattr(class_or_instance, _FIELDS)
  1034|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    except AttributeError:
  1035|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        raise TypeError('must be called with a dataclass type or instance')
  1036|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1037|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Exclude pseudo-fields.  Note that fields is sorted by insertion
  1038|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # order, so the order of the tuple is as the fields were defined.
  1039|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return tuple(f for f in fields.values() if f._field_type is _FIELD)
  1040|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1041|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1042|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _is_dataclass_instance(obj):
  1043|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Returns True if obj is an instance of a dataclass."""
  1044|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return hasattr(type(obj), _FIELDS)
  1045|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1046|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1047|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def is_dataclass(obj):
  1048|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Returns True if obj is a dataclass or an instance of a
  1049|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    dataclass."""
  1050|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    cls = obj if isinstance(obj, type) and not isinstance(obj, GenericAlias) else type(obj)
  1051|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return hasattr(cls, _FIELDS)
  1052|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1053|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1054|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def asdict(obj, *, dict_factory=dict):
  1055|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Return the fields of a dataclass instance as a new dictionary mapping
  1056|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    field names to field values.
  1057|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1058|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    Example usage:
  1059|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1060|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      @dataclass
  1061|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      class C:
  1062|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          x: int
  1063|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          y: int
  1064|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1065|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      c = C(1, 2)
  1066|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      assert asdict(c) == {'x': 1, 'y': 2}
  1067|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1068|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    If given, 'dict_factory' will be used instead of built-in dict.
  1069|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    The function applies recursively to field values that are
  1070|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    dataclass instances. This will also look into built-in containers:
  1071|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    tuples, lists, and dicts.
  1072|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """
  1073|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if not _is_dataclass_instance(obj):
  1074|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        raise TypeError("asdict() should be called on dataclass instances")
  1075|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return _asdict_inner(obj, dict_factory)
  1076|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1077|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1078|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _asdict_inner(obj, dict_factory):
  1079|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if _is_dataclass_instance(obj):
  1080|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        result = []
  1081|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        for f in fields(obj):
  1082|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            value = _asdict_inner(getattr(obj, f.name), dict_factory)
  1083|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            result.append((f.name, value))
  1084|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return dict_factory(result)
  1085|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif isinstance(obj, tuple) and hasattr(obj, '_fields'):
  1086|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # obj is a namedtuple.  Recurse into it, but the returned
  1087|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # object is another namedtuple of the same type.  This is
  1088|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # similar to how other list- or tuple-derived classes are
  1089|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # treated (see below), but we just need to create them
  1090|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # differently because a namedtuple's __init__ needs to be
  1091|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # called differently (see bpo-34363).
  1092|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1093|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # I'm not using namedtuple's _asdict()
  1094|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # method, because:
  1095|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # - it does not recurse in to the namedtuple fields and
  1096|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #   convert them to dicts (using dict_factory).
  1097|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # - I don't actually want to return a dict here.  The main
  1098|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #   use case here is json.dumps, and it handles converting
  1099|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #   namedtuples to lists.  Admittedly we're losing some
  1100|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #   information here when we produce a json list instead of a
  1101|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #   dict.  Note that if we returned dicts here instead of
  1102|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #   namedtuples, we could no longer call asdict() on a data
  1103|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #   structure where a namedtuple was used as a dict key.
  1104|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1105|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return type(obj)(*[_asdict_inner(v, dict_factory) for v in obj])
  1106|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif isinstance(obj, (list, tuple)):
  1107|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Assume we can create an object of this type by passing in a
  1108|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # generator (which is not true for namedtuples, handled
  1109|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # above).
  1110|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return type(obj)(_asdict_inner(v, dict_factory) for v in obj)
  1111|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif isinstance(obj, dict):
  1112|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return type(obj)((_asdict_inner(k, dict_factory),
  1113|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                          _asdict_inner(v, dict_factory))
  1114|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                         for k, v in obj.items())
  1115|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    else:
  1116|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return copy.deepcopy(obj)
  1117|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1118|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1119|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def astuple(obj, *, tuple_factory=tuple):
  1120|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Return the fields of a dataclass instance as a new tuple of field values.
  1121|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1122|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    Example usage::
  1123|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1124|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      @dataclass
  1125|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      class C:
  1126|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          x: int
  1127|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          y: int
  1128|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1129|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    c = C(1, 2)
  1130|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    assert astuple(c) == (1, 2)
  1131|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1132|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    If given, 'tuple_factory' will be used instead of built-in tuple.
  1133|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    The function applies recursively to field values that are
  1134|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    dataclass instances. This will also look into built-in containers:
  1135|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    tuples, lists, and dicts.
  1136|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """
  1137|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1138|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if not _is_dataclass_instance(obj):
  1139|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        raise TypeError("astuple() should be called on dataclass instances")
  1140|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return _astuple_inner(obj, tuple_factory)
  1141|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1142|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1143|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def _astuple_inner(obj, tuple_factory):
  1144|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if _is_dataclass_instance(obj):
  1145|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        result = []
  1146|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        for f in fields(obj):
  1147|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            value = _astuple_inner(getattr(obj, f.name), tuple_factory)
  1148|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            result.append(value)
  1149|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return tuple_factory(result)
  1150|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif isinstance(obj, tuple) and hasattr(obj, '_fields'):
  1151|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # obj is a namedtuple.  Recurse into it, but the returned
  1152|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # object is another namedtuple of the same type.  This is
  1153|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # similar to how other list- or tuple-derived classes are
  1154|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # treated (see below), but we just need to create them
  1155|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # differently because a namedtuple's __init__ needs to be
  1156|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # called differently (see bpo-34363).
  1157|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return type(obj)(*[_astuple_inner(v, tuple_factory) for v in obj])
  1158|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif isinstance(obj, (list, tuple)):
  1159|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Assume we can create an object of this type by passing in a
  1160|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # generator (which is not true for namedtuples, handled
  1161|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # above).
  1162|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return type(obj)(_astuple_inner(v, tuple_factory) for v in obj)
  1163|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    elif isinstance(obj, dict):
  1164|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return type(obj)((_astuple_inner(k, tuple_factory), _astuple_inner(v, tuple_factory))
  1165|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                          for k, v in obj.items())
  1166|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    else:
  1167|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return copy.deepcopy(obj)
  1168|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1169|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1170|         2|            0|            0|  0.00%|def make_dataclass(cls_name, fields, *, bases=(), namespace=None, init=True,
  1171|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|                   repr=True, eq=True, order=False, unsafe_hash=False,
  1172|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|                   frozen=False):
  1173|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Return a new dynamically created dataclass.
  1174|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1175|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    The dataclass name will be 'cls_name'.  'fields' is an iterable
  1176|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    of either (name), (name, type) or (name, type, Field) objects. If type is
  1177|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    omitted, use the string 'typing.Any'.  Field objects are created by
  1178|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    the equivalent of calling 'field(name, type [, Field-info])'.
  1179|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1180|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      C = make_dataclass('C', ['x', ('y', int), ('z', int, field(init=False))], bases=(Base,))
  1181|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1182|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    is equivalent to:
  1183|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1184|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      @dataclass
  1185|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      class C(Base):
  1186|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          x: 'typing.Any'
  1187|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          y: int
  1188|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          z: int = field(init=False)
  1189|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1190|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    For the bases and namespace parameters, see the builtin type() function.
  1191|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1192|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    The parameters init, repr, eq, order, unsafe_hash, and frozen are passed to
  1193|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    dataclass().
  1194|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """
  1195|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1196|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if namespace is None:
  1197|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        namespace = {}
  1198|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    else:
  1199|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Copy namespace since we're going to mutate it.
  1200|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        namespace = namespace.copy()
  1201|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1202|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # While we're looking through the field names, validate that they
  1203|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # are identifiers, are not keywords, and not duplicates.
  1204|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    seen = set()
  1205|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    anns = {}
  1206|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    for item in fields:
  1207|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if isinstance(item, str):
  1208|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            name = item
  1209|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            tp = 'typing.Any'
  1210|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        elif len(item) == 2:
  1211|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            name, tp, = item
  1212|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        elif len(item) == 3:
  1213|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            name, tp, spec = item
  1214|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            namespace[name] = spec
  1215|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        else:
  1216|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            raise TypeError(f'Invalid field: {item!r}')
  1217|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1218|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if not isinstance(name, str) or not name.isidentifier():
  1219|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            raise TypeError(f'Field names must be valid identifiers: {name!r}')
  1220|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if keyword.iskeyword(name):
  1221|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            raise TypeError(f'Field names must not be keywords: {name!r}')
  1222|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if name in seen:
  1223|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            raise TypeError(f'Field name duplicated: {name!r}')
  1224|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1225|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        seen.add(name)
  1226|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        anns[name] = tp
  1227|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1228|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    namespace['__annotations__'] = anns
  1229|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # We use `types.new_class()` instead of simply `type()` to allow dynamic creation
  1230|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # of generic dataclassses.
  1231|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    cls = types.new_class(cls_name, bases, {}, lambda ns: ns.update(namespace))
  1232|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return dataclass(cls, init=init, repr=repr, eq=eq, order=order,
  1233|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                     unsafe_hash=unsafe_hash, frozen=frozen)
  1234|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1235|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1236|         1|            0|            0|  0.00%|def replace(obj, /, **changes):
  1237|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    """Return a new object replacing specified fields with new values.
  1238|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1239|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    This is especially useful for frozen classes.  Example usage:
  1240|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1241|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      @dataclass(frozen=True)
  1242|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      class C:
  1243|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          x: int
  1244|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|          y: int
  1245|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1246|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      c = C(1, 2)
  1247|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      c1 = replace(c, x=3)
  1248|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      assert c1.x == 3 and c1.y == 2
  1249|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|      """
  1250|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1251|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # We're going to mutate 'changes', but that's okay because it's a
  1252|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # new dict, even if called with 'replace(obj, **my_changes)'.
  1253|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1254|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    if not _is_dataclass_instance(obj):
  1255|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        raise TypeError("replace() should be called on dataclass instances")
  1256|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1257|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # It's an error to have init=False fields in 'changes'.
  1258|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # If a field is not in 'changes', read its value from the provided obj.
  1259|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1260|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    for f in getattr(obj, _FIELDS).values():
  1261|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # Only consider normal fields or InitVars.
  1262|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if f._field_type is _FIELD_CLASSVAR:
  1263|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            continue
  1264|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1265|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if not f.init:
  1266|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            # Error if this field is specified in changes.
  1267|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            if f.name in changes:
  1268|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                raise ValueError(f'field {f.name} is declared with '
  1269|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                 'init=False, it cannot be specified with '
  1270|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                 'replace()')
  1271|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            continue
  1272|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1273|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if f.name not in changes:
  1274|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            if f._field_type is _FIELD_INITVAR and f.default is MISSING:
  1275|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                raise ValueError(f"InitVar {f.name!r} "
  1276|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                                 'must be specified with replace()')
  1277|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            changes[f.name] = getattr(obj, f.name)
  1278|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
  1279|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # Create the new object, which calls __init__() and
  1280|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # __post_init__() (if defined), using all of the init fields we've
  1281|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # added and/or left in 'changes'.  If there are values supplied in
  1282|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # changes that aren't fields, this will correctly raise a
  1283|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    # TypeError.
  1284|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    return obj.__class__(**changes)

   229|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   230|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # If a custom type is mixed into the Enum, and it does not know how
   231|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # to pickle itself, pickle.dumps will succeed but pickle.loads will
   232|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # fail.  Rather than have the error show up later and possibly far
   233|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # from the source, sabotage the pickle protocol for this class so
   234|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # that pickle.dumps also fails.
   235|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        #
   236|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # However, if the new class implements its own __reduce_ex__, do not
   237|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # sabotage -- it's on them to make sure it works correctly.  We use
   238|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # __reduce_ex__ instead of any of the others as it is preferred by
   239|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # pickle over __reduce__, and it handles all pickle protocols.

   245|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                    if '__new__' in classdict:

   358|        53|            0|            0|  0.00%|    def __call__(cls, value, names=None, *, module=None, qualname=None, type=None, start=1):
   359|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        """
   360|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        Either returns an existing member, or creates a new enum class.
   361|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   362|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        This method is used both when an enum class is given a value to match
   363|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        to an enumeration member (i.e. Color(3)) and for the functional API
   364|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        (i.e. Color = Enum('Color', names='RED GREEN BLUE')).
   365|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   366|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        When used for the functional API:
   367|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   368|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        `value` will be the name of the new class.
   369|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   370|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        `names` should be either a string of white-space/comma delimited names
   371|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        (values will start at `start`), or an iterator/mapping of name, value pairs.
   372|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   373|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        `module` should be set to the module this class is being created in;
   374|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if it is not set, an attempt to find that module will be made, but if
   375|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        it fails the class will not be picklable.
   376|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   377|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        `qualname` should be set to the actual location this class can be found
   378|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        at in its module; by default it is set to the global scope.  If this is
   379|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        not correct, unpickling will fail in some circumstances.
   380|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   381|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        `type`, if set, will be mixed in as the first base class.
   382|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        """
   383|        53|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if names is None:  # simple value lookup
   384|        53|            0|            0|  0.00%|            return cls.__new__(cls, value)
(call)|        53|  0.000997305|  1.88171e-05|  0.00%|# C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.9_3.9.3312.0_x64__qbz5n2kfra8p0\lib\enum.py:670 __new__
   385|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        # otherwise, functional API: we're creating a new Enum type
   386|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return cls._create_(
   387|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                value,
   388|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                names,

   395|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    def __contains__(cls, member):
   396|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        if not isinstance(member, Enum):
   397|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|            raise TypeError(
   398|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                "unsupported operand type(s) for 'in': '%s' and '%s'" % (
   399|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|                    type(member).__qualname__, cls.__class__.__qualname__))
   400|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        return isinstance(member, cls) and member._name_ in cls._member_map_
   401|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|
   402|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|    def __delattr__(cls, attr):

   420|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        class' __dict__ in order to support `name` and `value` being both

   422|         0|            0|            0|  0.00%|        enum members themselves.
